column5: (This December 2 story was corrected to change Morgan Stanley's North American ranking from No. 2 to No. 3)

column4: CORRECTED-Morgan Stanley names Collins to global healthcare banking co-head role: memo
column5: Dec 2 Morgan Stanley named John Collins as the co-head of its global healthcare banking group  according to an internal memo on Wednesday. He replaces Clint Gartin  who will become  chairman of investment banking.

column4: AIG offering up to $1 billion stake in Chinese insurer PICC P&C
column5: HONG KONG American International Group  (AIG) is selling a stake in PICC Property and Casualty Co Ltd  worth up to $1 billion to institutional investors through a block deal  cutting its shareholding in the Chinese state-owned insurer for the second time this year.

column4: National Oilwell Varco to cut another 900 Norwegian jobs
column5: OSLO  Dec 7 U.S. oilfield equipment maker National Oilwell Varco Inc will cut its Norwegian workforce by another 900 people after low oil prices resulted in fewer orders  the company said on Monday.

column4: Newell Rubbermaid  Jarden in talks to combine: source
column5: Newell Rubbermaid Inc   known for its Sharpie markers and Parker pens  is in talks to combine with consumer products company Jarden Corp   according to a person familiar with the matter who requested anonymity because the negotiations are confidential.

column4: UPDATE 3-Newell Rubbermaid  Jarden in talks to combine - source
column5: Dec 7 Newell Rubbermaid Inc  known for its Sharpie markers and Parker pens  is in talks to combine with consumer products company Jarden Corp  according to a person familiar with the matter who requested anonymity because the negotiations are confidential.

column4: Newell Rubbermaid  Jarden in talks to combine - WSJ
column5: Dec 7 Newell Rubbermaid Inc is in talks to combine with consumer products company Jarden Corp  the Wall Street Journal reported  citing people familiar with the matter.

column4: Ackman to join Canadian Pacific CEO in defense of rail deal
column5: Dec 7 When Canadian Pacific CEO Hunter Harrison lays out his case for a takeover of railway peer Norfolk Southern Corp  he will have unusual company in the form of the railroad's biggest shareholder  activist investor William Ackman.

column4: France's Orange in talks to buy Bouygues telecom  media assets: Bloomberg
column5: France's largest telecom operator  Orange SA  is in talks to buy telecommunication and media assets from Bouygues SA  Bloomberg reported on Monday  citing sources.

column5: * Sidney Taurel is to be appointed as Chairman with effect from 1 January 2016  Source text for Eikon:  Further company coverage:

column4: UPDATE 1-Brazil senator  top banker charged with blocking Petrobras probe
column5: SAO PAULO  Dec 7 Brazilian federal prosecutors presented formal charges against billionaire financier Andre Esteves and Senator Delcídio do Amaral on Monday  accusing them of obstructing a criminal investigation into state-run oil company Petrobras  according to a source familiar with the matter.

column4: Prudential likely to be first UK insurer to announce Solvency II ratios
column5: LONDON Britain's largest insurer Prudential said on Monday it would give an update on its capital position under new EU Solvency II rules on Jan. 19  ahead of other insurers who plan to issue ratios alongside annual earnings statements.

column4: BRIEF-Prudential to give "detailed update" on Solvency II on Jan 19
column5: * Solvency ii internal model approved by prudential regulation authority

column4: RBS teams up with investors to lend to private equity-backed UK firms
column5: LONDON  Dec 7 State-backed lender Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) has teamed up with a trio of big investment firms to lend up to 100 million pounds ($151 million) to mid-sized British companies that are backed by private equity firms.

column4: Taiwan's TSMC plans new China plant worth $3 billion
column5: TAIPEI Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co Ltd said it plans to set up its first advanced manufacturing plant in China with a $3 billion investment  highlighting the growing importance of the Chinese market for semiconductor giants.

column4: Taiwan's TSMC plans new China plant worth $3 bln
column5: TAIPEI  Dec 7 Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co Ltd said it plans to set up its first advanced manufacturing plant in China with a $3 billion investment  highlighting the growing importance of the Chinese market for semiconductor giants.

column4: Gannett to tap former Conde Nast Portfolio editor as content officer
column5: Gannett Co Inc  publisher of USA Today  has tapped Joanne Lipman  former editor in chief of Conde Nast Portfolio  as its first chief content officer  according to a company announcement scheduled to be released Monday that was reviewed by Reuters.

column4: UPDATE 1-JP Morgan has potential 10.1 pct stake in Telecom Italia
column5: MILAN  Dec 7 U.S. investment bank JP Morgan  has built up a long position equivalent to a 10.134 percent stake in Telecom Italia  a filing by Italian market watchdog Consob showed on Monday.

column4: Total agrees to pay $3.6 million to settle CFTC manipulation charge
column5: A North American unit of French oil company Total SA and a trader agreed to pay $3.6 million to settle charges of attempted manipulation of the U.S. natural gas market  the U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission said on Monday.

column4: Verizon could explore Yahoo's Internet business  CFO says
column5: Verizon Communications Inc's  chief financial officer Fran Shammo  said the No. 1 U.S. wireless carrier could look at buying Yahoo Inc's  core business  which includes Mail  its news and sports sites and advertising technology  if it is a good fit.

column4: Yum CFO to leave in February  amid China spinoff
column5: LOS ANGELES Yum Brands Inc  Chief Financial Officer Patrick Grismer will resign effective Feb. 19  the parent of the KFC  Taco Bell and Pizza Hut restaurant brands said on Monday.

column4: Yum CFO to leave in February  amid China spinoff

column4: Dunkin' Donuts says will switch to cage-free eggs by 2025
column5: Dunkin' Donuts  owned by Dunkin' Brands Group Inc   said it will switch to using cage-free eggs in the United States by 2025  becoming the latest restaurant company to announce plans to move away from eggs sourced from cage-confined chickens.
